   Assessment and Plan
   64M with nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy (EF 25%), severe AS s/p
   aortoplasty, rheumatic MS, DM, COPD, OSA & pulm HTN admitted to OSH
   with DOE, transferred for further evaluation of AS and found to have
   MSSA bacteremia, septic shock, and cardiogenic shock
   # Chronic systolic heart failure:  The patient
s signs of fluid
   overload (lower extremity and dependent back edema, crackles) are
   mildly better today than previously, and his urine output picked up to
   60-100cc/hr after starting milrinone and lasix. This suggests that
   milrinone, which enhances contractility and vasodilates peripherally,
   is helping the patient mobilize fluid forward in the context of his
   aortic stenosis and poor EF. Contractility is further enhanced by the
   digoxin he is taking for atrial fibrillation. Indeed, we know that
   milrinone and digoxin are working because his cardiac index (by Fick
   equation) is better today at 2.7 as compared to 1.8 yesterday morning.
   Furthermore, his creatinine is trending down today (1.1 today from
   2.2-ish over the past 3 days), and his UOP has picked up after starting
   the lasix (now 200cc+/hr over the past 7 hours). This further supports
   that increasing forward flow with milrinone is increasing blood flow
   through the kidney (increasing glomerular filtration rate as evidenced
   by decreasing creatinine) and that adding lasix is helping with the
   diuresis. We expect that he will continue to diurese significantly over
   the next 24 hours. The patient is otherwise on lopressor to decrease
   milrinone-associated tachycardia.
   -          Cont milrinone at 0.5 mcg/kg/min
   -          Cont digoxin, this AM level at 0.8 (subtherapeutic), may
   consider increasing to 0.250 mg
   -          Cont lasix at 15 mg/hour
   -          Goal fluid status -1L today (currently at -800 cc)
   -          Continue Metoprolol 12.5 mg po bid
   -          Continue to monitor hemodynamics
   -          Goal MAP>60
   -          Consider wedging him today to assess for some changes in
   fluid status (keeping in mind limitation of this measurement in the
   context of his aortic stenosis)
   # Atrial fibrillation:  Rate well controlled in the 80-90s on digoxin
   but his rhythm is still in atrial fibrillation. Will potentially need
   cardioversion in the future, which might even improve his cardiac
   output (thus decreasing the need for milrinone). If we decide to do
   cardioversion sooner than 3 weeks, we may need an echo to check for
   clot to prevent stroke.
   - Continue to monitor on telemetry
   - Continue Digoxin, consider increasing down
   - Beta-blocker for rate control, as above
   - Continue heparin gtt
   - Continue coumadin, goal INR [**1-23**], today at 1.6 (subtherapeutic)
   # Hemoptysis.  The patient has had nausea since yesterday and this AM
   he had hemoptysis. He most likely has an upper GI bleed secondary to
   his heparin.  We will need to discontinue the heparin and trend his
   hematocrit every 6 hours given the possible GI bleed. We will also
   place an NG tube to decompress and a PPI IV to decrease the bleeding,
   which we hope will relieve his nausea. Just in case his hematocrit
   drops too drastically, he has a type-and-cross active. Although he has
   not had a BM in 2 days, he has robust bowel sounds this morning and got
   a dulcolax, so we expect he should move his bowels soon. Given that he
   is on morphine (and we cannot discontinue because his back pain gets
   too severe), he will need to continue with a very robust bowel regimen.
   # Pulmonary hypertension:  Pulmonary pressures elevated out of
   proportion to what would be expected with aortic stenosis alone.
   Patient with known severe COPD. Has body habitus concerning for OSA as
   well, although has not be desaturating at night. Pulmonary consult
   service following; will weigh in again once patient is more euvolemic
   given that PCWP is still elevated.
   -          Pulmonary recs
   # Aortic stenosis:  s/p aortoplasty with minimal improvement in valve
   area. Transaortic pressure gradient did improve by 30mmHG. Once more
   medically stabilized, he may be a candidate for AVR.
   # MSSA bacteremia:  Unclear source; surveillance culture remain
   negative
    - Continue Nafcillin for 2 week course (day #1=[**2114-4-24**], day
   #14=[**2114-5-8**])
   .
   # Liver failure:  Transaminitis resolving, synthetic function
   improving. Likely [**1-22**] shock liver
   - Avoid hepatotoxic medications
   - Tylenol 2gm max/24 hrs
   .
   # ARF:  Creatinine trending down to 1.1, which suggests that the
   decrease in his GFR previously was due to poor forward flow and renal
   vein congestion (i.e. pre-renal ARF).
   -          Expect improvement as milrinone helps forward flow
   -          Closely monitor creatinine as we have increased Lasix gtt
   # Anemia
 Hct stable; unclear baseline; recent GIB w/ C-scope showing
   colonic AVM that was cauterized
   -          Trend hematocrit
   -          Guaiac stools
   .
   # Low back pain:  Presumed [**1-22**] chronic lumbar back disease, but will
   monitor for evidence of complication of bacteremia (epidural abscess)
   - Tramadol
   - Tylenol
   # Thrombocytopenia:  Stable. Likely a component of shock, liver
   failure, and bone marrow suppression from his bacteremia.
   .
   #DM
 well-controlled
   -cont basal, SS insulin
   .

   -cont statin

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, severe aortic stenosis, rheumatic mitral stenosis, diabetes, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with symptoms of dyspnea, tachypnea, and hemoptysis. He has a history of MSSA bacteremia, septic shock, and cardiogenic shock. The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Cardiac: Atrial fibrillation with a rate well-controlled in the 80-90s on digoxin. His cardiac index (CI) is improving, and his creatinine is trending down, indicating improved kidney function.
* Respiratory: The patient has COPD and OSA, with elevated pulmonary pressures. He is receiving oxygen therapy and has been advised to continue it.
* Hemodynamic: The patient's mean arterial pressure (MAP) is being closely monitored, and he is receiving vasopressors as needed.
* Renal: The patient's creatinine is trending down, indicating improving kidney function.
* Coagulation: The patient has a history of thrombocytopenia and is receiving heparin therapy.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has had nausea and hemoptysis, and an upper GI bleed is suspected. He is receiving proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy and an NG tube to decompress his stomach.
* Liver: The patient has transaminitis, but his synthetic function is improving.
* Anemia: The patient's hematocrit is stable, but his baseline is unclear. He has had a recent gastrointestinal bleed (GIB) and is being monitored for evidence of anemia.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation may lead to further complications, such as stroke or cardiogenic shock.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's COPD and OSA may worsen, leading to respiratory failure.
3. Renal complications: The patient's creatinine may continue to rise, indicating worsening kidney function.
4. Coagulation complications: The patient's thrombocytopenia may worsen, leading to bleeding complications.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's upper GI bleed may worsen, leading to further bleeding complications.
6. Liver complications: The patient's transaminitis may worsen, leading to liver failure.
7. Anemia complications: The patient's anemia may worsen, leading to further complications such as heart failure.

The patient's current medication regimen includes:

* Milrinone to improve cardiac output and reduce fluid overload
* Lasix to increase diuresis and reduce fluid overload
* Digoxin to control atrial fibrillation
* Heparin to prevent thrombosis
* Metoprolol to control heart rate
* Proton pump inhibitor (PPI) to prevent upper GI bleeding
* Tramadol for pain management
* Tylenol for pain management
* Statin for hyperlipidemia

The patient's future care plan includes:

* Continuing milrinone and lasix therapy
* Monitoring the patient's cardiac output and fluid status
* Adjusting the patient's medication regimen as needed
* Continuing to monitor the patient's respiratory status
* Considering cardioversion to convert the patient's atrial fibrillation to a normal sinus rhythm
* Monitoring the patient's liver function and adjusting therapy as needed
* Monitoring the patient's anemia and adjusting therapy as needed.

   64M with nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy (EF 25%), severe AS s/p

   with DOE, transferred for further evaluation of AS and found to have
   MSSA bacteremia, septic shock, and cardiogenic shock
   # Chronic systolic heart failure:  The patient
s signs of fluid
   overload (lower extremity and dependent back edema, crackles) are
   mildly better today than previously, and his urine output picked up to
   60-100cc/hr after starting milrinone and lasix. This suggests that
   milrinone, which enhances contractility and vasodilates peripherally,
   is helping the patient mobilize fluid forward in the context of his
   aortic stenosis and poor EF. Contractility is further enhanced by the
   digoxin he is taking for atrial fibrillation. Indeed, we know that
   milrinone and digoxin are working because his cardiac index (by Fick
   equation) is better today at 2.7 as compared to 1.8 yesterday morning.
   Furthermore, his creatinine is trending down today (1.1 today from
   2.2-ish over the past 3 days), and his UOP has picked up after starting
   the lasix (now 200cc+/hr over the past 7 hours). This further supports
   that increasing forward flow with milrinone is increasing blood flow
   through the kidney (increasing glomerular filtration rate as evidenced
   by decreasing creatinine) and that adding lasix is helping with the
   diuresis. We expect that he will continue to diurese significantly over
   the next 24 hours. The patient is otherwise on lopressor to decrease
   milrinone-associated tachycardia.

   -          Cont digoxin, this AM level at 0.8 (subtherapeutic), may

   -          Cont lasix at 15 mg/hour

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male with non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, severe aortic stenosis, rheumatic mitral stenosis, diabetes, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), obstructive sleep apnea, and pulmonary hypertension. He was admitted to the ICU with do not resuscitate (DNR) status due to septic shock, cardiogenic shock, and bacteremia.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Hemodynamics: The patient's cardiac index (by Fick equation) is better today at 2.7 compared to 1.8 yesterday morning. His creatinine is trending down today (1.1 today from 2.2-ish over the past 3 days), and his urine output has picked up after starting milrinone and lasix.
* Respiratory: The patient has mild bilateral crackles, and his oxygen saturation is 96%.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has a crescendo/decrescendo systolic murmur, loudest at the right upper sternal border, and normal S1 and S2 heart sounds.
* Renal: The patient's creatinine is 1.1, and his urine output has improved.
* Liver: The patient has transaminitis, but his synthetic function is improving.
* Hematological: The patient has thrombocytopenia, but it is stable.
* Nutritional: The patient is on a low-sodium, low-hydration diet with repletion of electrolytes as needed.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Cardiac complications:
	+ Atrial fibrillation may lead to stroke or embolic events.
	+ Cardiogenic shock may worsen if not managed properly.
	+ Aortic stenosis may worsen if not managed properly.
* Respiratory complications:
	+ Pulmonary hypertension may worsen if not managed properly.
	+ COPD may worsen if not managed properly.
* Renal complications:
	+ Acute kidney injury may worsen if not managed properly.
	+ Chronic kidney disease may worsen if not managed properly.
* Liver complications:
	+ Liver failure may worsen if not managed properly.
	+ Transaminitis may worsen if not managed properly.
* Hematological complications:
	+ Thrombocytopenia may worsen if not managed properly.
* Nutritional complications:
	+ Malnutrition may worsen if not managed properly.
* Other complications:
	+ Bacteremia may lead to sepsis or organ failure.
	+ Upper gastrointestinal bleed may worsen if not managed properly.
	+ Hemoptysis may worsen if not managed properly.

The patient's care plan includes:

* Continuing milrinone at 0.5 mcg/kg/min.
* Continuing digoxin at 0.8 mg (subtherapeutic) and considering increasing to 0.25 mg.
* Continuing lasix at 15 mg/hour.
* Monitoring hemodynamics and adjusting therapy as needed.
* Considering wedging the patient to assess for changes in fluid status.
* Continuing heparin gtt and coumadin, with a goal INR of 1.23.
* Discontinuing heparin due to hemoptysis and trending hematocrit every 6 hours.
* Placing an NG tube to decompress.
* Monitoring bowel movements and adjusting bowel regimen as needed.
* Continuing pulmonary consult service to assess for pulmonary hypertension.
* Considering AVR in the future.
* Monitoring for signs of liver failure and adjusting therapy as needed.
* Monitoring for signs of renal failure and adjusting therapy as needed.
* Monitoring for signs of anemia and adjusting therapy as needed.
* Monitoring for signs of low back pain and adjusting therapy as needed.
* Monitoring for signs of thrombocytopenia and adjusting therapy as needed.

Summary:

The patient, a 64-year-old male, is a critical care patient in the ICU with a complex medical history, including non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, severe aortic stenosis, rheumatic mitral stenosis, diabetes mellitus, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), and pulmonary hypertension. He was admitted to the hospital with decompensated heart failure, septic shock, and cardiogenic shock. He has undergone aortoplasty and is currently receiving treatment for MSSA bacteremia, septic shock, and cardiogenic shock.

The patient's 24-hour events are as follows:

* He had coffee-ground emesis and was placed on nasogastric (NG) suction with 200cc output to low suction.
* His hemodynamic monitoring showed a cardiac index (CI) of 3.7, which is an increase from 2.7 on Saturday.
* He is receiving IV fluids and diuretics, including furosemide (Lasix) and milrinone, to manage his fluid status and cardiac output.
* His blood pressure is currently 93/57 mmHg, and his heart rate is 100 bpm.
* He is receiving antibiotics for MSSA bacteremia, and his white blood cell count is elevated at 24.2 K/uL.
* He has been diagnosed with atrial fibrillation and is receiving anticoagulation therapy with heparin and coumadin.
* His liver function tests are abnormal, with transaminases elevated, and his creatinine level is trending down from 2.2 mg/dL to 1.1 mg/dL.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and blood pressure suggest that he may be experiencing sepsis.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac index is increasing, which may indicate cardiac failure or cardiogenic shock.
3. Liver failure: The patient's liver function tests are abnormal, which may indicate liver failure or chronic liver disease.
4. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, which may indicate renal failure or chronic kidney disease.
5. Pulmonary complications: The patient's pulmonary hypertension and COPD may increase his risk of pulmonary complications, such as pneumonia or respiratory failure.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's coffee-ground emesis and nasogastric suction may increase his risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding or perforation.
7. Neurological complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation and elevated heart rate may increase his risk of neurological complications, such as stroke or seizures.

Assessment and plan:

The patient's assessment and plan are as follows:

* Continue milrinone at 0.5 mcg/kg/min to manage his cardiac output.
* Continue furosemide (Lasix) at 5 mg/hour to manage his fluid status.
* Monitor his hemodynamic status and adjust his fluid and medication therapy as necessary.
* Continue antibiotics for MSSA bacteremia.
* Monitor his liver function tests and adjust his medication therapy as necessary.
* Monitor his creatinine level and adjust his fluid and medication therapy as necessary.
* Consider cardioversion for atrial fibrillation if his heart rate remains elevated.
* Monitor his pulmonary function tests and adjust his medication therapy as necessary.
* Monitor his gastrointestinal function and adjust his medication therapy as necessary.
* Monitor his neurological function and adjust his medication therapy as necessary.

   64M with nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy (EF 25%), severe AS s/p

   with DOE, transferred for further evaluation of AS and found to have
   MSSA bacteremia, septic shock, and cardiogenic shock
   # Chronic systolic heart failure:  The patient
s signs of fluid
   overload (lower extremity and dependent back edema, crackles) are
   mildly better today than previously, and his urine output picked up to
   60-100cc/hr after starting milrinone and lasix. This suggests that
   milrinone, which enhances contractility and vasodilates peripherally,
   is helping the patient mobilize fluid forward in the context of his
   aortic stenosis and poor EF. Contractility is further enhanced by the
   digoxin he is taking for atrial fibrillation. Indeed, we know that
   milrinone and digoxin are working because his cardiac index (by Fick
   equation) is better today at 2.7 as compared to 1.8 yesterday morning.
   Furthermore, his creatinine is trending down today (1.1 today from
   2.2-ish over the past 3 days), and his UOP has picked up after starting
   the lasix (now 200cc+/hr over the past 7 hours). This further supports
   that increasing forward flow with milrinone is increasing blood flow
   through the kidney (increasing glomerular filtration rate as evidenced
   by decreasing creatinine) and that adding lasix is helping with the
   diuresis. We expect that he will continue to diurese significantly over
   the next 24 hours. The patient is otherwise on lopressor to decrease
   milrinone-associated tachycardia.
   -          Cont milrinone at 0.5 mcg/kg/min
   -          Cont digoxin, this AM level at 0.8 (subtherapeutic), may
   consider increasing to 0.250 mg
   -          Cont lasix at 15 mg/hour
   -          Goal fluid status -1L today (currently at -800 cc)
   -          Continue Metoprolol 12.5 mg po bid
   -          Continue to monitor hemodynamics
   -          Goal MAP>60
   -          Consider wedging him today to assess for some changes in
   fluid status (keeping in mind limitation of this measurement in the
   context of his aortic stenosis)
   # Atrial fibrillation:  Rate well controlled in the 80-90s on digoxin
   but his rhythm is still in atrial fibrillation. Will potentially need
   cardioversion in the future, which might even improve his cardiac
   output (thus decreasing the need for milrinone). If we decide to do
   cardioversion sooner than 3 weeks, we may need an echo to check for
   clot to prevent stroke.
   - Continue to monitor on telemetry
   - Continue Digoxin, consider increasing down
   - Beta-blocker for rate control, as above
   - Continue heparin gtt
   - Continue coumadin, goal INR [**1-23**], today at 1.6 (subtherapeutic)
   # Hemoptysis.  The patient has had nausea since yesterday and this AM
   he had hemoptysis. He most likely has an upper GI bleed secondary to
   his heparin.  We will need to discontinue the heparin and trend his
   hematocrit every 6 hours given the possible GI bleed. We will also
   place an NG tube to decompress and a PPI IV to decrease the bleeding,
   which we hope will relieve his nausea. Just in case his hematocrit
   drops too drastically, he has a type-and-cross active. Although he has
   not had a BM in 2 days, he has robust bowel sounds this morning and got
   a dulcolax, so we expect he should move his bowels soon. Given that he
   is on morphine (and we cannot discontinue because his back pain gets
   too severe), he will need to continue with a very robust bowel regimen.
   # Pulmonary hypertension:  Pulmonary pressures elevated out of
   proportion to what would be expected with aortic stenosis alone.
   Patient with known severe COPD. Has body habitus concerning for OSA as
   well, although has not be desaturating at night. Pulmonary consult
   service following; will weigh in again once patient is more euvolemic
   given that PCWP is still elevated.
   -          Pulmonary recs
   # Aortic stenosis:  s/p aortoplasty with minimal improvement in valve
   area. Transaortic pressure gradient did improve by 30mmHG. Once more
   medically stabilized, he may be a candidate for AVR.
   # MSSA bacteremia:  Unclear source; surveillance culture remain
   negative
    - Continue Nafcillin for 2 week course (day #1=[**2114-4-24**], day
   #14=[**2114-5-8**])
   .
   # Liver failure:  Transaminitis resolving, synthetic function
   improving. Likely [**1-22**] shock liver
   - Avoid hepatotoxic medications
   - Tylenol 2gm max/24 hrs
   .
   # ARF:  Creatinine trending down to 1.1, which suggests that the
   decrease in his GFR previously was due to poor forward flow and renal
   vein congestion (i.e. pre-renal ARF).
   -          Expect improvement as milrinone helps forward flow
   -          Closely monitor creatinine as we have increased Lasix gtt
   # Anemia
 Hct stable; unclear baseline; recent GIB w/ C-scope showing

   -          Trend hematocrit
   -          Guaiac stools
   .
   # Low back pain:  Presumed [**1-22**] chronic lumbar back disease, but will

   - Tramadol

   # Thrombocytopenia:  Stable. Likely a component of shock, liver

 well-controlled

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, severe aortic stenosis, rheumatic mitral stenosis, diabetes, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). He was admitted to the ICU with doxorubicin, septic shock, and cardiogenic shock. He has been receiving milrinone and lasix for cardiac support and diuresis, respectively. The patient has had a significant improvement in his cardiac index (CI) and creatinine levels, suggesting that the milrinone is helping to improve forward flow and reduce renal vein congestion.

The patient has also had some concerning issues, including hemoptysis, which is likely due to an upper gastrointestinal bleed secondary to heparin. The heparin was discontinued, and the patient was placed on a nasogastric tube to decompress and a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) IV to decrease bleeding.

Other concerns include:

* Atrial fibrillation, which is well-controlled with digoxin, but may require cardioversion in the future.
* Pulmonary hypertension, which is elevated out of proportion to what would be expected with aortic stenosis alone.
* MSSA bacteremia, which is unclear in origin and may be related to the patient's underlying conditions.
* Liver failure, which is resolving and synthetic function is improving.
* Acute kidney injury (ARF), which is improving with milrinone and lasix.
* Anemia, which is stable but unclear baseline, and recent gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB) with colonoscopy showing colonic arteriovenous malformation (AVM) that was cauterized.
* Low back pain, which is presumed to be chronic lumbar back disease, but will be monitored for evidence of complication of bacteremia (epidural abscess).

Potential medical complications that can arise:

* Cardiac complications: continued atrial fibrillation, cardiogenic shock, or worsening of cardiac function.
* Pulmonary complications: worsening of pulmonary hypertension, pneumonia, or respiratory failure.
* Gastrointestinal complications: continued bleeding, perforation, or infection.
* Renal complications: worsening of acute kidney injury, electrolyte imbalance, or chronic kidney disease.
* Hepatic complications: worsening of liver failure, jaundice, or coagulopathy.
* Hematological complications: worsening of anemia, thrombocytopenia, or bleeding.
* Infectious complications: worsening of MSSA bacteremia, pneumonia, or sepsis.
* Neurological complications: worsening of low back pain, numbness, or weakness.
* Other complications: worsening of diabetes, hyperlipidemia, or obstructive sleep apnea.

   Assessment and Plan
   64M with nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy (EF 25%), severe AS s/p
   aortoplasty, rheumatic MS, DM, COPD, OSA & pulm HTN admitted to OSH
   with DOE, transferred for further evaluation of AS and found to have
   MSSA bacteremia, septic shock, and cardiogenic shock
   # Chronic systolic heart failure:  The patient
s signs of fluid
   overload (lower extremity and dependent back edema, crackles) are
   mildly better today than previously, and his urine output picked up to
   60-100cc/hr after starting milrinone and lasix. This suggests that
   milrinone, which enhances contractility and vasodilates peripherally,
   is helping the patient mobilize fluid forward in the context of his
   aortic stenosis and poor EF. Contractility is further enhanced by the
   digoxin he is taking for atrial fibrillation. Indeed, we know that
   milrinone and digoxin are working because his cardiac index (by Fick
   equation) is better today at 2.7 as compared to 1.8 yesterday morning.
   Furthermore, his creatinine is trending down today (1.1 today from
   2.2-ish over the past 3 days), and his UOP has picked up after starting
   the lasix (now 200cc+/hr over the past 7 hours). This further supports
   that increasing forward flow with milrinone is increasing blood flow
   through the kidney (increasing glomerular filtration rate as evidenced
   by decreasing creatinine) and that adding lasix is helping with the
   diuresis. We expect that he will continue to diurese significantly over
   the next 24 hours. The patient is otherwise on lopressor to decrease
   milrinone-associated tachycardia.
   -          Cont milrinone at 0.5 mcg/kg/min
   -          Cont digoxin, this AM level at 0.8 (subtherapeutic), may
   consider increasing to 0.250 mg
   -          Cont lasix at 15 mg/hour
   -          Goal fluid status -1L today (currently at -800 cc)
   -          Continue Metoprolol 12.5 mg po bid
   -          Continue to monitor hemodynamics
   -          Goal MAP>60
   -          Consider wedging him today to assess for some changes in
   fluid status (keeping in mind limitation of this measurement in the
   context of his aortic stenosis)
   # Atrial fibrillation:  Rate well controlled in the 80-90s on digoxin
   but his rhythm is still in atrial fibrillation. Will potentially need
   cardioversion in the future, which might even improve his cardiac
   output (thus decreasing the need for milrinone). If we decide to do
   cardioversion sooner than 3 weeks, we may need an echo to check for
   clot to prevent stroke.
   - Continue to monitor on telemetry
   - Continue Digoxin, consider increasing down
   - Beta-blocker for rate control, as above
   - Continue heparin gtt
   - Continue coumadin, goal INR [**1-23**], today at 1.6 (subtherapeutic)
   # Hemoptysis.  The patient has had nausea since yesterday and this AM
   he had hemoptysis. He most likely has an upper GI bleed secondary to
   his heparin.  We will need to discontinue the heparin and trend his
   hematocrit every 6 hours given the possible GI bleed. We will also
   place an NG tube to decompress and a PPI IV to decrease the bleeding,
   which we hope will relieve his nausea. Just in case his hematocrit
   drops too drastically, he has a type-and-cross active. Although he has
   not had a BM in 2 days, he has robust bowel sounds this morning and got
   a dulcolax, so we expect he should move his bowels soon. Given that he
   is on morphine (and we cannot discontinue because his back pain gets
   too severe), he will need to continue with a very robust bowel regimen.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, severe aortic stenosis, rheumatic mitral stenosis, diabetes mellitus, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with decompensated heart failure, septic shock, and cardiogenic shock. His condition has stabilized overnight, with a cardiac index of 3.7 and a creatinine level of 1.1. He is receiving milrinone and lasix infusions to manage his heart failure and diuresis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's cardiac index is still elevated, and he is at risk of developing cardiac arrest due to his underlying cardiomyopathy and aortic stenosis.
2. Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine level is still elevated, and he may be at risk of developing acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease due to his pre-existing kidney disease and the use of nephrotoxic medications.
3. GI Bleed: The patient has had hemoptysis and is at risk of developing a GI bleed due to his heparin therapy and underlying liver disease.
4. Pulmonary Hypertension: The patient's pulmonary pressures are elevated, and he may be at risk of developing right heart failure and pulmonary edema.
5. Infection: The patient has a bacteremia, and he is at risk of developing a secondary infection, such as sepsis or pneumonia.
6. Liver Failure: The patient has a history of liver disease, and he may be at risk of developing liver failure or exacerbation of his existing liver disease.
7. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is stable, but he may be at risk of developing anemia due to his underlying kidney disease and bleeding.
8. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is stable, but he may be at risk of developing thrombocytopenia due to his underlying bone marrow suppression and bleeding.
9. Low Back Pain: The patient has a history of low back pain, and he may be at risk of developing a complication, such as an epidural abscess, due to his bacteremia.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient will continue to receive milrinone and lasix infusions to manage his heart failure and diuresis. His heparin therapy will be discontinued due to his GI bleed, and he will receive an NG tube to decompress and a PPI IV to decrease bleeding. He will also receive a type-and-cross active in case of a GI bleed. The patient will be closely monitored for signs of cardiac arrest, renal failure, GI bleed, pulmonary hypertension, infection, liver failure, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and low back pain.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 69-inch tall, 122.7 kg male who is admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of chronic heart failure (CHF). The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6°C, heart rate of 100 bpm, blood pressure of 93/57 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. The patient's cardiac rhythm is atrial fibrillation.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 237 K/μL, hemoglobin of 9.0 g/dL, and platelet count of 228 K/μL. The patient's liver enzymes are elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 147 IU/L and an alkaline phosphatase (ALP) level of 59 IU/L. The patient's kidney function is impaired, with a creatinine level of 2.2 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 25 mg/dL.

The patient is receiving treatment for CHF, including diuretics and vasodilators. The patient is also receiving antibiotics for a possible infection. The patient's gastrointestinal symptoms are ongoing, with persistent nausea and vomiting. The patient's respiratory status is stable, with an oxygen saturation of 96% on room air.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on this information include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and liver enzymes may indicate an underlying infection, which could lead to sepsis.
2. Acute kidney injury: The patient's impaired kidney function and elevated creatinine level may indicate acute kidney injury.
3. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's persistent nausea and vomiting may indicate gastrointestinal bleeding, which could lead to further complications.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's ongoing respiratory symptoms and impaired oxygen saturation may indicate respiratory failure.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's low platelet count may indicate thrombocytopenia, which could lead to bleeding complications.
6. Heart failure exacerbation: The patient's ongoing CHF symptoms and impaired cardiac function may indicate an exacerbation of heart failure.
7. Infection: The patient's ongoing fever and elevated white blood cell count may indicate an underlying infection.
8. Liver dysfunction: The patient's elevated liver enzymes may indicate liver dysfunction, which could lead to further complications.

Based on this information, it is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to prevent and manage these potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   64M with nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy (EF 25%), severe AS s/p
   aortoplasty, rheumatic MS, DM, COPD, OSA & pulm HTN admitted to OSH
   with DOE, transferred for further evaluation of AS and found to have
   MSSA bacteremia, septic shock, and cardiogenic shock
   # SHOCK.  The patient
s biggest problem right now is shock in multiple
   forms: septic (as evidenced by increasing white count) and cardiogenic
   (poor EF, ventricular dyssynchrony, and myocardial stunning from
   sepsis).
   ***SEPTIC SHOCK***
   -          Elevated white count. The etiology of his septic shock is
   unclear. Although his UA was suspicious, his UCx is negative. His Foley
   was pulled and a new one was placed. He has negative CXR from
   yesterday. He still has diarrhea today but his stool c. diff is
   negative.  Blood cultures from yesterday are still NGTD, and we will
   send surveillance cultures today. Other potential sources include his
   cordis/swan and PICC lines.  We will consider pulling these lines
   today, possibly cordis/swan will be removed during this afternoon
   procedure. At this time we are treating his sepsis empirically.
   -          Pressors
    He was started on broad spectrum antibiotics, including vancomycin,
   zosyn, and flagyl, to cover most bugs that might be causing his shock.
   His c. diff came back negative yesterday.  Anion-gap metabolic acidosis
   suggests potential infectious etiology.
   ***Plan for treating septic shock:
   -          RUQ US to look for potential infectious source in biliary
   tree, check LFTs
   -          Will consider pulling cordis, swan, PICC line during the day
   as these might be possible source of infection. Note that the swan is
   coiled in the RA.
   -          goal MAPs >55, treated with phenylephrine and vasopressin
   ***Plan for treating cardiogenic shock:
   - He has been aneuric so he will be increasingly fluid overloaded as
   IVs are continued.
   - continue milrinone to increase contractility
   - cont metoprolol to decrease HR, thereby increasing SV
   - We may consider restarting digoxin, but because he has ARF he might
   not need it. ?check dig level
   - [**Month (only) 11**] need ablation or cardiac resync therapy to make his enhance his
   cardiac output
   # ARF. Cr. 3.2 from 2.2 yesterday in AM. BUN also rising (49 from low
   40s). Aneuric and he is getting more volume overloaded (especially
   arms), and he is becoming less oriented. Likely etiology is ATN,
   possibly from aggressive vasoconstriction with pressors as well as
   decreased perfusion pressure from sepsis.
   - Renal reccs are in
   - [**Month (only) 11**] need CVVH, not candidate for HD because his BP would drop too
   much. This should help his hyponatremia as well.
   # Afib. Rate is now better controlled on lopressor 100mg TID (BP
   controlled with pressors). Goals 60-70, now in the 80s. Also written
   for PRN lopressor in case it
s needed.
   # CHF. Cannot get volume off because aneuria, would need CVVH for this.
   # Leukocytosis. On Vanc, zosyn, flagyl. UA suspicious, UCx, BCx,
   pending. CXR (negative for PNA), and C.diff negative.
   # Pulmonary hypertension:  Pulmonary pressures elevated out of
   proportion to what would be expected with aortic stenosis alone.
   Patient with known severe COPD. Has body habitus concerning for OSA as
   well, although has not be desaturating at night. Pulmonary consult
   service following; will weigh in again once patient is more euvolemic
   given that PCWP is still elevated.
   -          Pulmonary recs
   # Aortic stenosis:  s/p aortoplasty with minimal improvement in valve
   area. Transaortic pressure gradient did improve by 30mmHG. Once more
   medically stabilized, he may be a candidate for AVR.
   # MSSA bacteremia:  Unclear source; surveillance culture remain
   negative.
    - No longer on nafcillin, but is otherwise covered by broad spectrum
   antibiotics.
   .
   # Liver failure:  Transaminitis resolving, synthetic function
   improving. Likely [**1-22**] shock liver
   - Avoid hepatotoxic medications
   - Tylenol 2gm max/24 hrs
   .
   # Anemia
 Hct stable; unclear baseline; recent GIB w/ C-scope showing
   colonic AVM that was cauterized
   -          Trend hematocrit
   -          Guaiac stools
   .
   # Low back pain:  Presumed [**1-22**] chronic lumbar back disease, but will
   monitor for evidence of complication of bacteremia (epidural abscess)
   - Tramadol
   - Tylenol
   # Thrombocytopenia:  Stable. Likely a component of shock, liver
   failure, and bone marrow suppression from his bacteremia.
   .
   #DM
 well-controlled
   -cont basal, SS insulin
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia
   -cont statin
   .
   # Access: Cordis/RIJ, PICC
   # Nutrition: NPO, needs D5W for low sugars, low Na/HH/DM diet replete
   lytes prn
   # Code: FULL
   # Dispo: CCU
   # Family:

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male with a complex medical history, including non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, severe aortic stenosis, rheumatic mitral stenosis, diabetes, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with decompensated heart failure, septic shock, and cardiogenic shock.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

1. Septic shock: Elevated white blood cell count, unclear etiology, and empiric treatment with broad-spectrum antibiotics.
2. Cardiogenic shock: Poor left ventricular function, ventricular dyssynchrony, and myocardial stunning from sepsis.
3. Acute kidney injury (AKI): Rapidly rising creatinine and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels, anuria, and need for continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT).
4. Atrial fibrillation (Afib): Rate-controlled with metoprolol, but with a goal of 60-70 beats per minute (bpm) and currently in the 80s.
5. Pulmonary hypertension: Elevated pulmonary pressures out of proportion to expected values, with a pulmonary consult service following.
6. Liver failure: Transaminitis resolving, synthetic function improving, and likely secondary to shock liver.
7. Anemia: Stable hematocrit, unclear baseline, and recent gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB) with a colonic arteriovenous malformation (AVM) that was cauterized.
8. Low back pain: Presumed chronic lumbar back disease, but monitoring for evidence of complications from bacteremia (epidural abscess).
9. Thrombocytopenia: Stable, likely secondary to shock, liver failure, and bone marrow suppression from bacteremia.
10. Diabetes: Well-controlled, with continued basal and short-acting insulin.
11. Hyperlipidemia: Continued statin therapy.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Sepsis-related organ dysfunction, such as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), acute liver failure, or acute pancreatitis.
2. Cardiogenic shock-related complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias, cardiac rupture, or cardiac tamponade.
3. AKI-related complications, such as electrolyte imbalances, acid-base disorders, or need for dialysis.
4. Pulmonary hypertension-related complications, such as right ventricular failure or pulmonary edema.
5. Liver failure-related complications, such as coagulopathy, ascites, or encephalopathy.
6. Anemia-related complications, such as fatigue, shortness of breath, or decreased exercise tolerance.
7. Low back pain-related complications, such as epidural abscess, spinal cord compression, or radiculopathy.
8. Thrombocytopenia-related complications, such as bleeding diathesis or increased risk of bleeding.

Given the patient's complex medical history and current condition, close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and address potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   64M with nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy (EF 25%), severe AS s/p
   aortoplasty, rheumatic MS, DM, COPD, OSA & pulm HTN admitted to OSH
   with DOE, transferred for further evaluation of AS and found to have
   MSSA bacteremia, septic shock, and cardiogenic shock
   # SHOCK.  The patient
s biggest problem right now is shock, both
   cardiogenic and septic, as evidenced by hypotension, anuria, change in
   mental status, and metabolic acidosis.
   ***SEPTIC SHOCK***
   -          The patient has a leukocytosis of 28, tachycardia,
   tachypnea, anion-gap metabolic acidosis, increasing need for pressors,
   all of which point towards a diagnosis of septic shock, but the
   etiology is unclear at this time. Although his UA was suspicious, his
   UCx is negative. His Foley was pulled and a new one was placed. He has
   negative CXR from yesterday. He still has diarrhea today but his stool
   c. diff is negative x1.  Blood cultures from yesterday are still NGTD,
   and we will send surveillance cultures today. Other potential sources
   include his cordis/swan and PICC lines.  Swan will be pulled this AM,
   other lines potentially pulled later today.
   -          At this time we are treating his sepsis empirically with
   vancomycin ([**2114-5-7**]=day 1), zosyn ([**2114-5-7**]=day 1), and flagyl
   ([**2114-5-7**]=day 1), awaiting blood cultures and sensitivities.
   -          We ordered ultrasound of abdomen to look for infectious
   source in biliary tree. Check LFTs as well.
   -          His profound hypotension is primarily due to sepsis. Because
   milrinone is contributing partially to his hypotension, we will try to
   wean it today. He is getting maximal doses of phenylephrine and
   vasopressin with a goal of MAP >55.
   ***CARDIOGENIC SHOCK***
   -          The patient has cardiogenic shock (i.e. cardiac pump failure
   as evidenced by poor EF), which is due to a combination of dilated
   cardiomyopathy, ventricular dyssynchrony, atrial fibrillation,
   tachycardia, and probable myocardial stunning from sepsis. Primary
   therapy to this point has been to treat him with inotropy (i.e.
   milrinone). He was also treated with amiodarone for a-fib and
   metoprolol for tachycardia, which we believe will increase his cardiac
   output by allowing for more time for better diastolic filling. Despite
   these efforts to increase his cardiac output, his SVR is dropping
   further (from sepsis) and his heart cannot increase the CO to
   sufficiently compensate. He will thus need to be taken to the cath lab
   this PM to undergo cardioversion (to reverse a-fib and thus decrease
   tachycardia), and [**Hospital1 **]-ventricular pacing to reverse his ventricular
   dyssynchrony.
   -          He is getting maximal doses of phenylephrine and vasopressin
   with a goal of MAP >55.
   # ARF. Cr. 3.2 from 2.2 yesterday in AM. BUN also rising (49 from low
   40s). Aneuric and he is getting more volume overloaded (especially
   arms), and he is becoming less oriented. Likely etiology is ATN,
   possibly from aggressive vasoconstriction with pressors as well as
   decreased perfusion pressure from sepsis.
   - Will call renal consult
   - [**Month (only) 11**] need CVVH (not candidate for HD because his BP would drop too
   much). Indications would include severe volume overload (i.e.
   increasing O2 requirement, which he does not need right now), uremia
   (including metabolic acidosis), or severe electrolyte abnormalities.
   # Afib. Rate is now better controlled on lopressor 100mg TID (BP
   controlled with pressors). Goals 60-70, now in the 80s. Also written
   for PRN lopressor in case it
s needed.
   # CHF. More fluid overloaded today than previously. Cannot get volume
   off because anuria, would need CVVH for this, renal was consulted will
   leave a note today.
   # Leukocytosis. Trending up, most likely due to an infection.
   Empirically treated on Vanc, zosyn, flagyl (all day 2). UA suspicious,
   UCx, BCx, pending. CXR (negative for PNA), and C.diff negative x1.
   # Pulmonary hypertension:  Pulmonary pressures elevated out of
   proportion to what would be expected with aortic stenosis alone.
   Patient with known severe COPD. Has body habitus concerning for OSA as
   well, although has not be desaturating at night. Pulmonary consult
   service following; will weigh in again once patient is more euvolemic
   given that PCWP is still elevated.
   -          Pulmonary recs
   # Aortic stenosis:  s/p aortoplasty with minimal improvement in valve
   area. Transaortic pressure gradient did improve by 30mmHG. Once more
   medically stabilized, he may be a candidate for AVR.
   # MSSA bacteremia:  Unclear source; surveillance culture remain
   negative.
    - No longer on nafcillin (14 day course), but is otherwise covered by
   broad spectrum antibiotics.
   .
   # Coagulopathy. The patient
s INR is up today again, at 2.8. Etiology

   - f/u DIC labs

Based on the provided physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male with a complex medical history, including non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, severe aortic stenosis, rheumatic mitral stenosis, diabetes mellitus, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and obstructive sleep apnea. He is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) due to cardiogenic shock, septic shock, and acute kidney injury.

The patient's condition is critical, with a severe ventricular dysynchrony, atrial fibrillation, and a cardiac output that is insufficient to meet his metabolic demands. He is receiving inotropic support with milrinone and vasopressors, including phenylephrine and vasopressin, to maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 55 mmHg.

The patient's septic shock is likely caused by a combination of factors, including a presumed MSSA bacteremia, sepsis, and cardiogenic shock. His anion gap metabolic acidosis, increasing need for pressors, and tachycardia and tachypnea all point towards a diagnosis of septic shock. The etiology of his sepsis is unclear, but potential sources include his cordis/swan and PICC lines.

The patient's acute kidney injury is likely due to a combination of factors, including sepsis, cardiogenic shock, and the use of vasopressors. His creatinine level has risen to 3.2 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) is also increasing. He is at risk for further kidney damage and may require continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT).

The patient's liver function tests (LFTs) are abnormal, with elevated levels of alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST). His international normalized ratio (INR) is elevated at 2.8, likely due to shock liver from sepsis and the use of vasopressors.

The patient's anemia is likely due to a combination of factors, including gastrointestinal bleeding, chronic lumbar back disease, and bone marrow suppression from his bacteremia.

The patient's thrombocytopenia is likely due to a combination of factors, including sepsis, liver failure, and bone marrow suppression from his bacteremia.

The patient's hyperlipidemia is likely due to his diabetes mellitus and the use of statins.

The patient's low back pain is likely due to a combination of factors, including chronic lumbar back disease and the use of vasopressors.

The patient's DM is well-controlled with basal and sliding scale insulin.

The patient's hyperlipidemia is likely due to his diabetes mellitus and the use of statins.

The patient's ICU care plan includes:

* Nutrition: NPO, low Na/HH/DM diet replete lytes prn
* Glycemic control: needs D5W for low sugars
* Lines: PICC line, PA catheter
* Prophylaxis: DVT, stress ulcer, VAP
* Code status: Full code
* Disposition: CCU

   64M with nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy (EF 25%), severe AS s/p

   MSSA bacteremia, septic shock, and cardiogenic shock
   # SHOCK.  The patient
s biggest problem right now is shock, both
   cardiogenic and septic, as evidenced by hypotension, anuria, change in
   mental status, and metabolic acidosis.
   ***SEPTIC SHOCK***
   -          The patient has a leukocytosis of 28, tachycardia,
   tachypnea, anion-gap metabolic acidosis, increasing need for pressors,
   all of which point towards a diagnosis of septic shock, but the
   etiology is unclear at this time. Although his UA was suspicious, his
   UCx is negative. His Foley was pulled and a new one was placed. He has
   negative CXR from yesterday. He still has diarrhea today but his stool
   c. diff is negative.  Blood cultures from yesterday are still NGTD, and
   we will send surveillance cultures today. Other potential sources
   include his cordis/swan and PICC lines.  Swan will be pulled this AM,
   other lines potentially pulled later today.
   -          At this time we are treating his sepsis empirically with
   vancomycin, zosyn, and flagyl, awaiting blood cultures and
   sensitivities.
   -          We ordered ultrasound of abdomen to look for infectious
   source in biliary tree. Check LFTs as well.
   -          His profound hypotension is primarily due to sepsis although
   milrinone is also contributing. He is getting maximal doses of
   phenylephrine and vasopressin with a goal of MAP >55.
   ***CARDIOGENIC SHOCK***
   -          The patient has cardiogenic shock (i.e. cardiac pump failure
   as evidenced by poor EF), which is due to a combination of dilated
   cardiomyopathy, ventricular dyssynchrony, atrial fibrillation,
   tachycardia, and probable myocardial stunning from sepsis. Primary
   therapy to this point has been to treat him with inotropy (i.e.
   milrinone). He was also treated with amiodarone for a-fib and
   metoprolol for tachycardia, which we believe will increase his cardiac
   output by allowing for more time for better diastolic filling. Despite
   these efforts to increase his cardiac output, his SVR is dropping
   further (from sepsis) and his heart cannot increase the CO to
   sufficiently compensate. He will thus need to be taken to the cath lab
   this PM to undergo cardioversion (to reverse a-fib and resultingly
   decrease tachycardia), and [**Hospital1 **]-ventricular pacing to reverse his
   ventricular dyssynchrony.
   # ARF. Cr. 3.2 from 2.2 yesterday in AM. BUN also rising (49 from low
   40s). Aneuric and he is getting more volume overloaded (especially
   arms), and he is becoming less oriented. Likely etiology is ATN,
   possibly from aggressive vasoconstriction with pressors as well as
   decreased perfusion pressure from sepsis.
   - Renal reccs are in
   - [**Month (only) 11**] need CVVH, not candidate for HD because his BP would drop too
   much. This should help his hyponatremia as well.
   # Afib. Rate is now better controlled on lopressor 100mg TID (BP
   controlled with pressors). Goals 60-70, now in the 80s. Also written
   for PRN lopressor in case it
s needed.
   # CHF. Cannot get volume off because anuria, would need CVVH for this,
   renal was consulted will leave recs today.
   # Leukocytosis. On Vanc, zosyn, flagyl. UA suspicious, UCx, BCx,
   pending. CXR (negative for PNA), and C.diff negative.
   # Pulmonary hypertension:  Pulmonary pressures elevated out of
   proportion to what would be expected with aortic stenosis alone.
   Patient with known severe COPD. Has body habitus concerning for OSA as
   well, although has not be desaturating at night. Pulmonary consult
   service following; will weigh in again once patient is more euvolemic
   given that PCWP is still elevated.
   -          Pulmonary recs

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male with non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, severe aortic stenosis, rheumatic mitral stenosis, diabetes mellitus, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), and pulmonary hypertension. He was admitted to the hospital with symptoms of dyspnea on exertion and was found to have methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) bacteremia, septic shock, and cardiogenic shock.

The patient's current condition is severe, with a diagnosis of septic shock and cardiogenic shock. He has a leukocytosis of 28, tachycardia, tachypnea, anion-gap metabolic acidosis, and increasing need for pressors. His blood cultures are pending, and he is receiving empiric treatment with vancomycin, zosyn, and flagyl.

The patient has several potential sources of sepsis, including his cordis/swan and PICC lines. His stool culture is negative for Clostridium difficile, and his urinary culture is pending.

The patient's cardiogenic shock is due to a combination of dilated cardiomyopathy, ventricular dyssynchrony, atrial fibrillation, tachycardia, and probable myocardial stunning from sepsis. He is receiving inotropy with milrinone and is being considered for cardioversion and ventricular pacing.

The patient's renal function is impaired, with a creatinine level of 3.2 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 49 mg/dL. He is anuric and is receiving volume overload, which is likely contributing to his worsening mental status.

The patient's electrolyte levels are abnormal, with a potassium level of 4.3 mEq/L and a phosphorus level of 5.4 mg/dL. His magnesium level is 2.4 mg/dL, and his calcium level is 8.4 mg/dL.

The patient's liver function is impaired, with a transaminase level of 147 IU/L and a bilirubin level of 2.7 mg/dL. His synthetic function is improving, and he is likely experiencing shock liver.

The patient has a history of anemia, which is likely related to his gastrointestinal bleeding and colonic arteriovenous malformation. He is also experiencing low back pain, which is likely related to his chronic lumbar back disease.

The patient's thrombocytopenia is likely related to his bacteremia, liver failure, and bone marrow suppression. His platelet count is 28,000/μL.

The patient's medications include vancomycin, zosyn, flagyl, milrinone, amiodarone, metoprolol, and heparin. He is also receiving nutritional support with D5W and a low-sodium diet.

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is to the cardiac care unit (CCU).

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

* Septic shock: This patient is at risk for further deterioration and death from septic shock.
* Cardiogenic shock: This patient is at risk for further cardiac deterioration and death from cardiogenic shock.
* Renal failure: This patient is at risk for further deterioration of his renal function and may require dialysis.
* Liver failure: This patient is at risk for further deterioration of his liver function and may require liver transplantation.
* Anemia: This patient is at risk for further anemia and may require blood transfusions.
* Low back pain: This patient is at risk for further complications from his low back pain, including epidural abscess.
* Thrombocytopenia: This patient is at risk for further thrombocytopenia and may require platelet transfusions.
* Hyperglycemia: This patient is at risk for further hyperglycemia and may require insulin therapy.
* Hyperlipidemia: This patient is at risk for further hyperlipidemia and may require lipid-lowering therapy.
* Pulmonary hypertension: This patient is at risk for further deterioration of his pulmonary hypertension and may require pulmonary vasodilators.
* Aortic stenosis: This patient is at risk for further deterioration of his aortic stenosis and may require aortic valve replacement.

   # SHOCK.  The patient
s biggest problem right now is shock in multiple
   forms: septic (as evidenced by increasing white count) and cardiogenic

   sepsis). The etiology of his septic shock currently seems to be urinary
   given his UA, but we will need to f/u on urince cultures. He was

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male with a complex medical history, including non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, severe aortic stenosis, rheumatic mitral stenosis, diabetes mellitus, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), and pulmonary hypertension. He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with symptoms of dyspnea on exertion, septic shock, and cardiogenic shock.

The patient's current medical condition is characterized by:

1. Septic shock: The patient has a urinary tract infection (UTI) and is receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover potential pathogens. His white blood cell count is increasing, and his blood cultures are pending.
2. Cardiogenic shock: The patient has poor left ventricular function (EF 25%), ventricular dyssynchrony, and myocardial stunning from sepsis. He is receiving milrinone to increase contractility and metoprolol to decrease heart rate and increase stroke volume.
3. Acute kidney injury (ARF): The patient's creatinine level has increased from 2.2 to 3.2 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is rising. He is anuric and volume overloaded, which may be contributing to his decreased mental status.
4. Atrial fibrillation (AF): The patient's heart rate is currently in the 80s, and he is receiving metoprolol to control his heart rate.
5. Pulmonary hypertension: The patient's pulmonary pressures are elevated, which may be contributing to his respiratory distress.
6. Liver failure: The patient has transaminitis, which is resolving, and his synthetic function is improving. He may have liver failure due to shock or sepsis.
7. Anemia: The patient's hematocrit is stable, but his baseline is unclear. He has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding and may have a colonic arteriovenous malformation (AVM).
8. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is stable, but it may be a component of his shock, liver failure, and bone marrow suppression from his bacteremia.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Continued septic shock: The patient's UTI may not be fully treated, and he may develop further complications such as pneumonia or meningitis.
2. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's poor left ventricular function and ventricular dyssynchrony may worsen, leading to further cardiogenic shock.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's ARF may progress to chronic kidney disease or require renal replacement therapy.
4. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's AF may worsen, leading to further heart rate variability and decreased cardiac output.
5. Pulmonary hypertension: The patient's elevated pulmonary pressures may worsen, leading to further respiratory distress.
6. Liver failure: The patient's liver function may continue to deteriorate, leading to further synthetic dysfunction and potential liver failure.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen, leading to further fatigue and decreased oxygen delivery to his tissues.
8. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may worsen, leading to further bleeding complications.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Continuing broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover potential pathogens.
2. Managing his cardiogenic shock with milrinone, metoprolol, and potentially restarting digoxin.
3. Treating his ARF with continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) and potentially restarting dialysis.
4. Managing his AF with metoprolol and potentially restarting digoxin.
5. Monitoring his pulmonary hypertension and potentially treating with pulmonary vasodilators.
6. Monitoring his liver function and potentially treating with hepatoprotective medications.
7. Monitoring his anemia and potentially treating with blood transfusions.
8. Monitoring his thrombocytopenia and potentially treating with platelet transfusions.

The patient's disposition is to the cardiac care unit (CCU), and he is currently receiving full code status.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Septic Shock: The patient's septic shock is not yet fully controlled, and the etiology is unclear. The patient's blood cultures are pending, and surveillance cultures will be sent. The patient is being treated empirically with vancomycin, zosyn, and flagyl.
2. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient has cardiogenic shock due to poor left ventricular function, ventricular dyssynchrony, and myocardial stunning from sepsis. The patient is being treated with milrinone to increase contractility, metoprolol to decrease heart rate, and vasopressin to increase blood pressure.
3. Acute Renal Failure (ARF): The patient's creatinine level has risen to 3.2 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is increasing. The patient is at risk for further kidney damage due to sepsis, hypovolemia, and the use of nephrotoxic medications.
4. Hypovolemic Shock: The patient is at risk for hypovolemic shock due to his aneuric state and the use of vasopressors, which can cause vasoconstriction and decreased blood flow to the kidneys.
5. Liver Failure: The patient's liver function tests are abnormal, and he is at risk for further liver damage due to sepsis, hypovolemia, and the use of hepatotoxic medications.
6. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, and he is at risk for further platelet dysfunction due to sepsis, liver failure, and bone marrow suppression from his bacteremia.
7. Anemia: The patient's hematocrit is stable, but he is at risk for further anemia due to ongoing bleeding, hemolysis, or bone marrow suppression.
8. Low Back Pain: The patient has low back pain, which may be due to chronic lumbar back disease or a complication of bacteremia (epidural abscess).
9. Pulmonary Hypertension: The patient has pulmonary hypertension, which may be due to his underlying COPD, OSA, or aortic stenosis.
10. Aortic Stenosis: The patient has severe aortic stenosis, which may require surgical intervention in the future.

To address these potential complications, the patient will require close monitoring and management in the ICU. The patient's antibiotic regimen will need to be adjusted based on the results of his blood cultures and sensitivities. The patient's fluid status will need to be closely monitored to prevent hypovolemic shock, and his vasopressor therapy will need to be adjusted to optimize his blood pressure. The patient's liver function will need to be closely monitored to prevent further liver damage, and his platelet count will need to be monitored to prevent bleeding complications. The patient's anemia will need to be managed with blood transfusions if necessary, and his low back pain will need to be managed with pain medication and further evaluation to rule out a complication of bacteremia.

Based on the provided physician's daily progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

**Current Condition:**

The patient is in septic shock, cardiogenic shock, and acute kidney injury (AKI). He has a history of non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, severe aortic stenosis, rheumatic mitral stenosis, diabetes mellitus, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). He was admitted to the hospital with decompensated heart failure, and later developed septic shock and cardiogenic shock.

**Physiological Parameters:**

* Blood pressure: 86/47 mmHg
* Heart rate: 91 bpm
* Respiratory rate: 22 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 94%
* Central venous pressure (CVP): 26 mmHg
* Pulmonary artery pressure (PAP): 90/26 mmHg
* Cardiac output (CO): 4.8 L/min
* Cardiac index (CI): 2.1 L/min/m2
* Mixed venous oxygen saturation: 45-45%
* Total fluid intake: 3,590 mL
* Total fluid output: 945 mL

**Laboratory Results:**

* White blood cell count (WBC): 28.5 K/uL
* Hemoglobin (Hb): 9.2 g/dL
* Platelet count (Plt): 196 K/uL
* Creatinine (Cr): 3.2 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 49 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.4 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.8 g/dL
* LDH: 562 IU/L
* Calcium: 8.4 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.4 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 5.4 mg/dL

**Medical Complications:**

* Septic shock: The patient is in septic shock, likely due to MSSA bacteremia, with a leukocytosis of 28, tachycardia, tachypnea, anion-gap metabolic acidosis, and increasing need for pressors.
* Cardiogenic shock: The patient has cardiogenic shock due to dilated cardiomyopathy, ventricular dyssynchrony, atrial fibrillation, tachycardia, and probable myocardial stunning from sepsis.
* Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient has AKI, likely due to ATN, possibly from aggressive vasoconstriction with pressors as well as decreased perfusion pressure from sepsis.
* Coagulopathy: The patient has a coagulopathy, likely due to shock liver from sepsis and sepsis itself, with an INR of 2.8.
* Liver failure: The patient has liver failure, likely due to shock liver, with transaminitis resolving and synthetic function improving.
* Anemia: The patient has anemia, likely due to gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB) with a colonic arteriovenous malformation (AVM) that was cauterized.
* Thrombocytopenia: The patient has thrombocytopenia, likely due to shock, liver failure, and bone marrow suppression from bacteremia.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

* Pulmonary hypertension: The patient has pulmonary hypertension, likely due to COPD and OSA.
* Aortic stenosis: The patient has aortic stenosis, which may require further evaluation and management.
* MSSA bacteremia: The patient has MSSA bacteremia, with an unclear source, and surveillance cultures remain negative.
* C.diff infection: The patient has been treated for C.diff infection, but the results are pending.

**Plan:**

* Continue empiric antibiotics for MSSA bacteremia.
* Wean milrinone and phenylephrine to optimize cardiac output.
* Consider cardioversion and ventricular pacing to reverse atrial fibrillation and ventricular dyssynchrony.
* Monitor for signs of pulmonary hypertension and consider pulmonary consultation.
* Continue to monitor for signs of liver failure and consider liver transplantation if necessary.
* Consider CVVH for AKI and volume overload.
* Monitor for signs of coagulopathy and bleeding.
* Continue to monitor for signs of sepsis and adjust management accordingly.
* Consider further evaluation and management of aortic stenosis.
* Monitor for signs of C.diff infection and adjust management accordingly.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual with multiple comorbidities. The patient's medical history includes chronic diastolic heart failure, aortic stenosis, and atrial fibrillation.

The patient's current condition is marked by acute renal failure, gastrointestinal bleeding, sepsis without organ dysfunction, and thrombocytopenia. The patient's vital signs are unstable, with a heart rate of 91 beats per minute, blood pressure of 86/47 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 94%.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, lactate dehydrogenase, and creatinine levels, indicating potential organ dysfunction. The patient's coagulation profile is also abnormal, with a prolonged prothrombin time, partial thromboplastin time, and international normalized ratio.

The patient's respiratory status is compromised, with a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute and a partial pressure of oxygen in arterial blood of 20 mmHg. The patient's neurological status is also compromised, with a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 8.

The patient's medical treatment plan includes vasopressin, phenylephrine, and milrinone infusions to support blood pressure and cardiac function. The patient is also receiving antibiotics, including nafcillin, ciprofloxacin, and vancomycin, to treat potential sepsis. The patient's pain is being managed with opioids, and their nutritional needs are being met through total parenteral nutrition.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Sepsis progression to septic shock
2. Renal failure progression to acute kidney injury
3. Gastrointestinal bleeding progression to hemorrhagic shock
4. Thrombocytopenia progression to bleeding diathesis
5. Respiratory failure progression to acute respiratory distress syndrome
6. Cardiac failure progression to cardiogenic shock
7. Neurological deterioration due to hypoxia or sepsis

The patient's clinical course is being closely monitored, and further interventions will be necessary to address these potential complications and improve the patient's clinical outcomes.

   Assessment and Plan
   64M with nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy (EF 25%), severe AS s/p
   aortoplasty, rheumatic MS, DM, COPD, OSA & pulm HTN admitted to OSH
   with DOE, transferred for further evaluation of AS and found to have
   MSSA bacteremia, septic shock, and cardiogenic shock
   # SHOCK.  The patient
s biggest problem right now is shock in multiple
   forms: septic (as evidenced by increasing white count) and cardiogenic
   (poor EF, ventricular dyssynchrony, and myocardial stunning from
   sepsis). The etiology of his septic shock currently seems to be urinary
   given his UA but his UCx is negative. He was started on broad spectrum
   antibiotics, including vancomycin, zosyn, and flagyl, to cover most
   bugs that might be causing his shock. His c. diff came back negative
   yesterday.  Anion-gap metabolic acidosis suggests potential infectious
   etiology.
   ***Plan for treating septic shock:
   -          RUQ US to look for potential infectious source in biliary
   tree, check LFTs
   -          Will consider pulling cordis, swan, PICC line during the day
   as these might be possible source of infection. Note that the swan is
   coiled in the RA.
   -          goal MAPs >55, treated with phenylephrine and vasopressin
   ***Plan for treating cardiogenic shock:
   - He has been aneuric so he will be increasingly fluid overloaded as
   IVs are continued.
   - continue milrinone to increase contractility
   - cont metoprolol to decrease HR, thereby increasing SV
   - We may consider restarting digoxin, but because he has ARF he might
   not need it. ?check dig level
   - [**Month (only) 11**] need ablation or cardiac resync therapy to make his enhance his
   cardiac output
   # ARF. Cr. 3.2 from 2.2 yesterday in AM. BUN also rising (49 from low
   40s). Aneuric and he is getting more volume overloaded (especially
   arms), and he is becoming less oriented. Likely etiology is ATN,
   possibly from aggressive vasoconstriction with pressors as well as
   decreased perfusion pressure from sepsis.
   - Renal reccs are in
   - [**Month (only) 11**] need CVVH, not candidate for HD because his BP would drop too
   much. This should help his hyponatremia as well.
   # Afib. Rate is now better controlled on lopressor 100mg TID (BP
   controlled with pressors). Goals 60-70, now in the 80s. Also written
   for PRN lopressor in case it
s needed.
   # CHF. Cannot get volume off because aneuria, would need CVVH for this.
   # Leukocytosis. On Vanc, zosyn, flagyl. UA suspicious, UCx, BCx,
   pending. CXR (negative for PNA), and C.diff negative.
   # Pulmonary hypertension:  Pulmonary pressures elevated out of
   proportion to what would be expected with aortic stenosis alone.
   Patient with known severe COPD. Has body habitus concerning for OSA as
   well, although has not be desaturating at night. Pulmonary consult
   service following; will weigh in again once patient is more euvolemic
   given that PCWP is still elevated.
   -          Pulmonary recs
   # Aortic stenosis:  s/p aortoplasty with minimal improvement in valve
   area. Transaortic pressure gradient did improve by 30mmHG. Once more
   medically stabilized, he may be a candidate for AVR.
   # MSSA bacteremia:  Unclear source; surveillance culture remain
   negative.
    - No longer on nafcillin, but is otherwise covered by broad spectrum
   antibiotics.
   .
   # Liver failure:  Transaminitis resolving, synthetic function
   improving. Likely [**1-22**] shock liver
   - Avoid hepatotoxic medications
   - Tylenol 2gm max/24 hrs
   .
   # Anemia
 Hct stable; unclear baseline; recent GIB w/ C-scope showing
   colonic AVM that was cauterized
   -          Trend hematocrit
   -          Guaiac stools
   .
   # Low back pain:  Presumed [**1-22**] chronic lumbar back disease, but will
   monitor for evidence of complication of bacteremia (epidural abscess)
   - Tramadol
   - Tylenol
   # Thrombocytopenia:  Stable. Likely a component of shock, liver
   failure, and bone marrow suppression from his bacteremia.
   .
   #DM
 well-controlled
   -cont basal, SS insulin
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia
   -cont statin

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-year-old male with a complex medical history, including non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, severe aortic stenosis, rheumatic mitral stenosis, diabetes mellitus, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). He was admitted to the hospital with dyspnea on exertion and was found to have MSSA bacteremia, septic shock, and cardiogenic shock.

The patient's current condition is critical, with septic shock, cardiogenic shock, and acute kidney injury (AKI). He is anuric and has a rising creatinine level, which suggests a high risk of progression to renal failure. He also has an elevated lactate level, which suggests poor tissue perfusion.

The patient's cardiac condition is complex, with severe aortic stenosis, ventricular dyssynchrony, and myocardial stunning from sepsis. He has a history of aortoplasty and may require further intervention to improve cardiac output.

The patient's respiratory status is also compromised, with COPD and OSA. He has a history of pulmonary hypertension and may require further evaluation and management to optimize his respiratory function.

The patient's laboratory results are concerning, with an elevated white blood cell count, elevated lactate level, and elevated creatinine level. His blood cultures are pending, but he has already received broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover potential pathogens.

The patient's medical plan includes:

1. Treatment of septic shock:
	* RUQ US to look for potential infectious source in the biliary tree
	* Consider pulling cordis, swan, and PICC line as potential sources of infection
	* Goal MAPs >55, treated with phenylephrine and vasopressin
2. Treatment of cardiogenic shock:
	* Continue milrinone to increase contractility
	* Continue metoprolol to decrease heart rate and increase stroke volume
	* Consider restarting digoxin, but may not be necessary due to anuria
	* Ablation or cardiac resynchronization therapy may be necessary to improve cardiac output
3. Treatment of AKI:
	* Renal replacement therapy (CVVH) may be necessary to manage fluid overload and electrolyte imbalances
4. Treatment of hyperglycemia:
	* Continue basal and short-acting insulin
5. Treatment of hyperlipidemia:
	* Continue statin therapy

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Worsening of septic shock
2. Progression to renal failure
3. Development of respiratory failure
4. Cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac arrest
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding
6. Hepatic failure
7. Thrombocytopenia
8. Coagulopathy

The patient's plan of care should be closely monitored and adjusted as necessary to address these potential complications and optimize his outcomes.

   # SHOCK.  The patient
s biggest problem right now is shock, both
   cardiogenic and septic, as evidenced by hypotension, anuria, change in
   mental status, and metabolic acidosis.
   ***SEPTIC SHOCK***
   -          The patient has a leukocytosis of 28, tachycardia,
   tachypnea, anion-gap metabolic acidosis, increasing need for pressors,
   all of which point towards a diagnosis of septic shock, but the
   etiology is unclear at this time. Although his UA was suspicious, his

   negative CXR from yesterday. He still has diarrhea today but his stool
   c. diff is negative x1.  Blood cultures from yesterday are still NGTD,
   and we will send surveillance cultures today. Other potential sources
   include his cordis/swan and PICC lines.  Swan will be pulled this AM,
   other lines potentially pulled later today.
   -          At this time we are treating his sepsis empirically with
   vancomycin ([**2114-5-7**]=day 1), zosyn ([**2114-5-7**]=day 1), and flagyl
   ([**2114-5-7**]=day 1), awaiting blood cultures and sensitivities.
   -          We ordered ultrasound of abdomen to look for infectious
   source in biliary tree. Check LFTs as well.
   -          His profound hypotension is primarily due to sepsis. Because
   milrinone is contributing partially to his hypotension, we will try to
   wean it today. He is getting maximal doses of phenylephrine and
   vasopressin with a goal of MAP >55.
   ***CARDIOGENIC SHOCK***
   -          The patient has cardiogenic shock (i.e. cardiac pump failure
   as evidenced by poor EF), which is due to a combination of dilated
   cardiomyopathy, ventricular dyssynchrony, atrial fibrillation,
   tachycardia, and probable myocardial stunning from sepsis. Primary
   therapy to this point has been to treat him with inotropy (i.e.
   milrinone). He was also treated with amiodarone for a-fib and
   metoprolol for tachycardia, which we believe will increase his cardiac
   output by allowing for more time for better diastolic filling. Despite
   these efforts to increase his cardiac output, his SVR is dropping
   further (from sepsis) and his heart cannot increase the CO to
   sufficiently compensate. He will thus need to be taken to the cath lab
   this PM to undergo cardioversion (to reverse a-fib and thus decrease
   tachycardia), and [**Hospital1 **]-ventricular pacing to reverse his ventricular
   dyssynchrony.

   with a goal of MAP >55.

   40s). Aneuric and he is getting more volume overloaded (especially
   arms), and he is becoming less oriented. Likely etiology is ATN,
   possibly from aggressive vasoconstriction with pressors as well as
   decreased perfusion pressure from sepsis.

   - [**Month (only) 11**] need CVVH (not candidate for HD because his BP would drop too

s needed.
